text: Nothing kills snack time quite like staleness.

Your palate deserves better than that bland,
bendy tortilla chip or that crusty, brittle

bread, so we’ve worked out the chemical
basics of staling for you.

All the better give you some pro-tips to maximize
your snacking potential - just in time for
football season.

Bread and chips both get stale, but why is
it that bread get harder, while chips get
softer?

The answer has a lot to do with moisture,
but not moisture exclusively.

The whole process of staling hasn’t been
completely figured out by scientists at this
point, but major factors have been identified.
First let’s take a quick look at bread.

Inside a loaf of bread you’re going to find
webs of wheat flour proteins, or gluten, and
also starch molecules.

These webs create scaffolding around tiny
carbon dioxide air pockets that are created

by yeasts when they munch down on sugars in
the bread while it rises.

This structure is what makes bread inherently
spongy.
It also helps keep moisture in.

The starches in bread are made up of two primary
units, amylose and amylopectin.

When bread is baked, the amylose molecules
break down and lose their moisture within
the first day of the loaf’s life.

You can tell they’re still in good shape
when bread is really fresh out of the oven
and easily sliced.

The amylopectin, on the other hand, form crystalline
structures that keep moisture trapped in place
much longer.

It is the slow breakdown of these molecules
that inevitably let moisture out of the bread,
giving it that hard, crumbly texture.

Now, as for those chips, it’s all about
moisture.

Chips lose nearly all their moisture when
they’re flash fried, which evaporates off
thanks to the high heat of the oil.

Both chips and bread contain a lot of starch
molecules, which are hydrophilic by nature,
that is, they absorb water.

Perfectly dried out fried chips make these
starches pretty thirsty so they grab water
molecules from the air around them.

This water then softens the chips, making
them lose their addictive crunch.
Bummer.

This process also happens to breads when hydrophilic
starches in the crust suck moisture from the

interior of the loaf, leaving it dried out
and stale.

So if air softens chips, why don’t they
come out of the bag soft already?
I mean look at this bag, it’s like a balloon.

One study suggested that some chip bags can
contain upwards of 86% air inside, inviting

sustainable critique – that’s a lot thin
air being delivered all over the world.

But get this folks, chip bag engineers are
ahead of the staleness curve.

Those bags aren’t filled with plain old
air -- they’re filled with nitrogen gas.

Nitrogen is an inert gas which means it’s
less reactive than other gasses in the air.

Also when the bags are inflated, there is
no moisture included into the mix, making
your chips stay nice and crispy inside.

And for the record here folks, the reason
chip bags are so inflated is to keep the chips
from being crushed when in transit.

Okay so now that we’ve got the basics down,
what’s the best way to keep your loaf nice
and fresh?
Pro Tip: Temperature is key.

Bread stored in the refrigerator will go stale
up to six times faster than bread kept at
room temperature.

On the other hand, a loaf that’s well sealed
in foil or plastic and put in the freezer
will keep the longest.

If you plan to eat your loaf in one to two
days, using a bread box or paper bag does
the best job at maintaining moisture.

Don’t use plastic bags because they end
up trapping in expelled moisture from the
staling process.

That can lead to moisture buildup and blue-green
mold growth.

Now how about salvaging your stale bread and
chips?
You wouldn’t believe how easy it is.

For chips, throw them into your microwave
on high for thirty seconds and nearly all

of that moisture will leave, giving you a
seemingly brand new, crunchy batch.

As for your bread, a newly staled loaf can
be tossed in the oven at 60°C and reheated
to help them suck up more moisture.
Problem solved.
